case_vignette: A 77-year-old man comes to your office for a routine visit. He is doing well, and his only complaint is the recent appearance of several brown greasy appearing lesions on his forehead (figure A) that he can't seem to peel off.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've noticed some brown, greasy-looking spots on my forehead that just won't come off.
How long have you had these spots?
They've shown up recently.
Have these spots changed in size, color, or shape since you noticed them?
No, they haven't changed in size, color, or shape since I noticed them.
Do the spots itch, burn, or cause any other discomfort?
No, they don't itch, burn, or cause any discomfort.
How old are you, and what is your sex?
I am a 77-year-old man.
Do you have a history of similar skin issues or any other skin conditions?
No, I haven't had similar skin issues or any other skin conditions before.
Are you currently taking any medications?
I'm here for a routine visit, but I haven't mentioned any medications.
Do you have a family history of skin cancer or any genetic skin disorders?
I haven't said anything about a family history of skin cancer or genetic skin disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic keratosis.
